utterances: There's a lot that changes all at once with something like travel.
So you're exposing yourself to different microbes.
You're exposing yourself to different food.
There's stress involved.
So that's another condition that's thought to have a microbiome component, but the causality for that hasn't been pinned down just yet.
And here's a tweet coming in from Shaza(ph), who says: Could this have some role in understanding skin diseases like psoriasis?
Absolutely.
So I - when I say that the skin is a desert, again, there's - it certainly doesn't mean that there aren't microbes there, and it doesn't mean that they don't interact with our immune system.
That's thought to be one of the potential links to conditions like psoriasis or atopic dermatitis.
Let's get a quick last question in from Dan in Eugene, Oregon.
Hi, Dan.
Quickly.
Hi.
Yeah.
Is there any difference between - everything being normal otherwise - any difference in the ratio of these different microorganisms (unintelligible)...
Which are the most?
Yeah, what kind of exactly different - can you name the different kinds of microbes you're talking about?
I see.
So each body area represents sort of a major group of microbial ecologies, and just like macroecologies tend to be populated by a few dominant organisms, the same thing is true in the microbiome.
So each of these - the five major areas that we looked at for these body sites tended to have a couple dominant bugs there.

So, for example, the streptococci and the oral cavity, where different streptococci might be dominant in most individuals, or the bacteroides or members of the firmicutes in the gut were dominant in most people, varying from person to person.
Thank you very much, Dr. Huttenhower, for taking time to be with us today.
Excellent.
Thanks again.
Good luck to you.
Dr. Curtis Huttenhower is assistant professor in the Department of Biostatistics at Harvard Public School of - Harvard School of Public Health.
He helped coordinate the Human Microbiome Project Consortium's analysis paper in Nature.
We're going to take a break, but we're still going be talking about bugs and bacteria.
There are some that wear armor.
They have a suit of armor that looks just like chainmail, and we've seen it now for the first time.
We'll tell you what it looks like after this break.
So stay with us.
We'll be right back.
That is a word that doesn't come up often.
What I do know, that I'm clear on is that the need for those who will organize, who will stand and speak truth to power in this country is a tremendously important patriotic act.
And it is needed now and in some ways more than it was needed then because there are attempts to literally remove or undo what has been done.
And so patriotism requires us to not only fight to hold on to the things of the past but to fight to push to the victories that we have not yet won.
The Reverend William Barber II.
And throughout today's program, we'll hear more voices about the meaning of patriotism.
As Christine said, track & field is no longer on the cover of major magazines, and it's not often on primetime television at the Olympics either.
This was a deliberate decision by NBC scheduling with the Olympic committee.
Howard Rosenberg is the Pulitzer Prize-winning television critic, formerly with the Los Angeles Times.
Howard, NBC has such power, they can tell the Olympics when to schedule their events.
Yes, I think they can, and you know, that goes all across the board when networks televise big events.
And I think it's a shame, because it really, in effect, disenfranchises people who really look forward to track & field, and I'm speaking for myself.
And they're even so - even the gymnastics, even though they're in primetime, on the West Coast, they're so late that it goes past people's bedtimes.
I do wonder about that scheduling.
I mean, just in the office here, people are complaining that NBC puts these events on in primetime, but then the real stuff that you want to see, it gets later and later and later, after 10:00?
Yeah, well, you know, I'm sure they have research that tells them that Michael Phelps is somebody people want to see, and they do that all the time.
They designate a star, and they go with him.
And in this case, it did work because Phelps won a lot and became a big star.
Speaking personally, I'm a little tired of it.
I mean, you know, he's everywhere.
You'll turn on your microwave in the morning and he pops up on the screen.
I'd like to see a little less of that and some more - some other things and not only the Americans, because this is an international event, not just an ethnocentric American event.
You know, it's a television event, though, isn't it?
And I wonder, how is NBC doing as television?

Well, it must be doing well, because its numbers, its ratings, are very high, and I mean, it's a real colossus, and I think, in part, because of curiosity about China, and also, as I said, because NBC has made this Olympics so widely available.
I remember past Olympic television networks - I'm thinking ABC in particular - jumping around from event to event.
You'd be some place two minutes.
You'd go someplace else.

It's not like that this year, and I thought that I would enjoy that a lot, but then we spend just an amazing amount of time on beach volleyball and I wondered, come on, something else must be happening.
I do have a problem with some of the continuity.

For example, in the men's individual gymnastics, they promoted it all evening, showed just a little bit of it before moving on to swimming, I assume, because the Americans were prominent in swimming, and the male gymnastics, they were not.
Let me ask you just finally here about the business of all this, the numbers for NBC, the ratings, just absolutely huge.
NBC also told Daily Variety this week that in the first five days of coverage, more than 17 million people streamed to these video events onto their phones for downloading.
I wonder about that.
Maybe that's why you're seeing the close up of those faces so much.
Maybe they're thinking about really small screens, one image.
Well, I don't necessarily think that's true because that was happening way back when ABC did the Olympics.

You know, not a lot has changed since then and including the jingoism of the coverage which is something people don't talk about a lot, but I think is really important to discuss because I'm one of those people who - I don't share to believe that the Olympics necessarily brings a planet together in some kind of people spirit.
I think it's just the opposite and I think what the problem is it increases a sort of nationalistic fervor among nations.
But sports are international and I couldn't care less which nation gets the most or least medals.
You just like to watch those games and see people do amazing things.
Absolutely, and lip sync.
Los Angeles Times critic Howard Rosenberg, his new book, ""No Time To Think: The Menace of Media Speed and the 24-Hour News Cycle,"" comes out in the next couple of months.
Howard, thank you.
My pleasure.
From NPR News it's Day to Day.
It's another day and so it's another record price for oil.
Today, 132 dollars a barrel.
That happened after the energy department released a new report.
It said that supplies of crude and refined oil unexpectedly fell last week.
The pressure is now on Congress to come up with some answers.
Today, a senate panel is grilling oil and gas executives about the price run up.
Marketplace's Janet Babin is here with the details and Janet, what do the senators say is behind these high gas prices?
Well, Madeleine, Committee Chairman, Patrick Leahy, the Democrat from Vermont, said that there's this unexplained disconnect between supply and demand and prices.
Other committee members blame OPEC price collusion for the runaway prices.
I asked Jorge Pinon about these comments, about OPEC price explosion in particular.

He's an energy fellow at the Center for Hemispheric Policy at the University of Miami, and he just didn't see how this would be possible because, OPEC, he says only controls about 37 percent of the world's crude oil production.
The rest happens in countries like Brazil, Russia and the U.S.
and Penyon says the only member of OPEC that is not at maximum capacity, right now, is Saudi Arabia.
Saudi is the only country in the world that is today is in a position to open the valves and put, rather quickly, the matter at bay - the additional oil in the marketplace.
I should note here that Pinon is also a former oil exec.
He worked at AMICO and BP, but he said he doesn't receive any funding from oil companies.
OK, so we are talking about crude oil, what about what we pay at the pump?
Don't oil companies have some say over how much is paid there?
Rapper 50 Cent has penned his second autobiography.
It's titles, ""50 x 50"" and it hits stores this week.
In the book, 50 talks candidly about his tough childhood and his rise from the streets to the recording studio.
The book also includes personal essays, handwritten song lyrics and baby pictures.
Noah Callahan-Bever co-authored the book.
He's also the editor-in-chief of Complex magazine.
Noah joins me now to talk about the upcoming issue and his new book.
Welcome back to the show.
Hello, thank you.
So the October issue hits stores next week, and there's an article counterfeit sneakers called Faking the funk(ph).
So, what exactly are we talking about here?
One of the things that has become more and more prevalent as sneaker culture has grown is basically bootleg sneakers have been popping up all across the country.
You go on eBay and you'll see very, very cheap prices on things that, you know, you know at a sneaker boutique, either New York or L.A., you know, you pay hundreds of dollars for it.
Yet somehow, someone in Taiwan is selling it for $40.
And it's tens of millions of dollars.
Oh, yes.
Chinese bootleg sneakers account for 81 percent of all the counterfeit merchandise that enters into the United States, according to customs authorities, 81 percent out of 135 million.
Well, let's move on to the book that co-authored with 50 Cent.
So how did you sit down with him and process what you were going to put into it?
I've known 50 for the better part of 10 years at this point.

You know, we would sit down for two or three hours, and you know, we just look at the photos and, you know, I'd get him to sort of tell me stories about them, sort of the players and who the people are in them.
And then also just sort of recounting these little sort of vignettes from his life.
And then I just sort of, you know, helped to put them all together into one sort of somewhat more cohesive narrative.
When you think about the fact that just last year, he published a New York Times bestselling biography, ""From Pieces to Weight,"" what's new about what you've just done?
All the visual stuff that he came to the table with me, there's pictures of him as a child, pictures of him in juvenile detention centers, all kinds of crazy stuff that no one's ever seen before.

The beautiful part about doing ""50 x 50"" was that, because we had the photos to inform the narratives, it enabled us to sort of tell a lot of sort of interesting asides that weren't able to be covered in any of the sort of more straightforward, you know, tellings of his story.
There's a great picture of him with his grandmother, his aunt at a picnic at a drug rehab program.
What exactly is that about?
Well, he was, I think about 15 or 16, he got busted for having a crack in his shoe and basically they tested him for drugs.
And although he wasn't a drug user, he - because he had been cooking up crack and using his hands to cut the coke, it absorbed through his pores and he was, you know, tested positive.
And so, basically his lawyer got the judge to agree to send him to a drug rehabilitation clinic rather than to send him to a juvenile detention center.
And so he ended up going through that.
And it's a very interesting sort of learning process, you know?
He definitely attributed a lot of his ability to manipulate and his ability to discipline himself.
It talks about physical discipline.
Do you ever think, okay, I'm working with this guy whose really talented, but he used to be a dealer, he talks all the time about getting shot.
What kind of message am I sending to 12, 14-year-olds?
Is this really what I should be doing?
Hmm.
To be honest, I don't really ever feel particularly conflicted by that.
I think that he is fascinating person and incredibly intelligent person.
And I think that, you know, really the takeaway from his story should not be sort of the glorification of the negative side of his life.

What's so interesting is how sort of fiercely analytical he is in his approach to life and how pragmatic he is in sort of overcoming the adversities and sort of the bad things that were thrown his way.
